newsitem.title: UK: Dated Brent set to plunge, other grades steady.
newsitem.headline: Dated Brent set to plunge, other grades steady.

text.p: Dated Brent was offered aggressively lower on Wednesday, but differentials for other North Sea grades were steady, traders said.

A Brent cargo loading June 12-14 which was passed through the paper chains on Wednesday and kept by BP, was reoffered late in the afternoon at July Brent -20 cents, 23 cents off a trade on Tuesday and 37 cents off last week's traded high.
Traders said that Brent was ripe for a fall having been kept artificially high by a trading house trying to support a CFD position.
"It's been coming off steadily but it's ready to really drop now," said one trader.
Two other Brent cargoes which were originally nominated loading dates on Wednesday were deferred.

CFDs were also under pressure with next week's dates (June 2-6) heard sold at July Brent -28 cents, and June 16-20 at August -35 cents, or the equivalent to around July -23 cents. The following week was traded twice at August Brent -34 cents.
July Brent was trading two cents higher at $19.24 a barrel on the IPE screen at 1711 GMT, having traded on the paper market at $19.32 and $19.23.
Brent intermonth spreads were also weaker, with July/August traded at a low of -14 cents.
But other North Sea grades, having failed to respond to Brent's galloping gains last week, held steady.
"It's been a separate market and it's pretty well supported, there's some good refinery demand out there," said one Norwegian producer.
A June 21-23 Oseberg traded at Dated Brent +15 cents, a Statfjord loading June 6-8 fetched Dated Brent +33 cents, while a Beryl traded earlier at a healthy Dated Brent +$1.00.
